title: Structural JSON index (GIN-style path/containment queries)
notes:
The current JSON extractor flattens shallow JSON into key=value pairs with dot-separated paths. This works for flat/simple JSON logs but falls short for deeply nested structures, arrays of objects, and keys that contain dots.

A proper structural JSON index would support:
- Arrays of objects: spans[*].attributes.db.statement
- Deep nesting beyond 4 levels
- Distinguishing dotted keys (service.name as single key) from nested paths
- Containment queries (does this record's JSON contain this sub-structure)
- Path existence queries

Conceptually similar to PostgreSQL's GIN index for JSONB. Would likely need a new index format and query syntax extensions.

title: Backpressure signaling
description: Signal backpressure from chunk managers to ingesters when ingestion is too fast.
notes:
Go's blocking semantics provide basic backpressure for free — if chunk Append blocks, the ingester goroutine stops reading from the network, TCP buffers fill, and the sender slows down.

This issue covers explicit backpressure beyond the implicit kind:
- Return HTTP 429 / RELP NACK instead of just being slow
- Drop low-priority messages under load instead of blocking everything
- Observable metrics on queue depth and backpressure events
- Configurable buffer limits before implicit backpressure kicks in

The backend now enforces auth on all non-public endpoints (2bod). The frontend needs:

1. Auth state management: React context for token storage (localStorage), auth status
2. Transport interceptor: attach Authorization Bearer header to all Connect RPC requests
3. Auth client: instantiate AuthService client in client.ts
4. Registration screen: shown when GetAuthStatus returns needs_setup=true (no users exist)
5. Login screen: shown when user has no valid token but users exist
6. Auth hooks: useLogin, useRegister, useAuthStatus, useLogout
7. Route guard: redirect to login/register when unauthenticated

The frontend should call GetAuthStatus on startup to determine whether to show registration or login. After successful login/register, store the token and attach it to all subsequent requests.

title: Separate certificate storage from TLS server settings in config store
description:
PutTLSConfig and GetTLSConfig on the Store interface conflate two unrelated concerns: certificate data (PEM content, file paths) stored in the tls_certificates table, and TLS server settings (enabled, redirect, default_cert) stored in the settings table as part of server config JSON. This coupling causes a non-atomicity issue — PutTLSConfig writes server settings first, then certs in a separate transaction — and is redundant with PutServerConfig which already manages TLS server settings through its own read-modify-write path.

Replace GetTLSConfig/PutTLSConfig with dedicated certificate CRUD methods on the Store interface (e.g. ListCertificates, GetCertificate, PutCertificate, DeleteCertificate). TLS server settings stay exclusively in server config. The API layer's PutCertificate calls both independently: save the cert, then update server config if set_as_default is set.

description:

Implementation details:
- Glob patterns for file discovery (param: paths, comma-separated, e.g. /var/log/*.log,/opt/app/logs/*.log)

- Slow background poll as safety net for edge cases (param: poll_interval, default 30s, 0 to disable)
- Position bookmarking in <datadir>/state/tail/<ingester_id>.json, persisted across restarts
- Log rotation detection: inode tracking, truncation detection (file shrinks)
- Re-evaluation of glob patterns for new/removed files via fsnotify on parent directories
- Line-delimited: supports both \n and \r\n, each line = one IngestMessage
- SourceTS left as zero (separate issue gastrolog-1n9u handles extraction from content)
- Params: paths (required), poll_interval (default 30s)

- Falls back to configurable poll interval as safety net

- Resumes from last position after restart

Each component accepts children/ReactNode props for custom content (React's equivalent of slots). Tabs like Certificates and Users with unique behaviors (drag-and-drop, password reset) just pass their custom UI through these slots.

SettingsCard stays as-is — it already handles expand/collapse/delete well.

Separate certificate storage from TLS server settings in config store
description:
PutTLSConfig and GetTLSConfig on the Store interface conflate two unrelated concerns: certificate data (PEM content, file paths) stored in the tls_certificates table, and TLS server settings (enabled, redirect, default_cert) stored in the settings table as part of server config JSON. This coupling causes a non-atomicity issue — PutTLSConfig writes server settings first, then certs in a separate transaction — and is redundant with PutServerConfig which already manages TLS server settings through its own read-modify-write path.

Replace GetTLSConfig/PutTLSConfig with dedicated certificate CRUD methods on the Store interface (e.g. ListCertificates, GetCertificate, PutCertificate, DeleteCertificate). TLS server settings stay exclusively in server config. The API layer's PutCertificate calls both independently: save the cert, then update server config if set_as_default is set.
